title: Pi Piscis Austrini
text:
Pi Piscis Austrini, <a href="Latinisation%20of%20names">Latinized</a> from π Piscis Austrini, is <a href="binary%20star">binary star</a> system in the <a href="Southern%20celestial%20hemisphere">southern</a> <a href="constellation">constellation</a> of <a href="Piscis%20Austrinus">Piscis Austrinus</a>, near the eastern constellation border with <a href="Sculptor%20%28constellation%29">Sculptor</a>. It has a yellow-white hue and is visible to the <a href="naked%20eye">naked eye</a> as a dim point of light with an <a href="apparent%20visual%20magnitude">apparent visual magnitude</a> of 5.12. The system is located at a distance of 92 <a href="light-year">light-year</a>s from the <a href="Sun">Sun</a> based on <a href="stellar%20parallax">parallax</a>. Its <a href="radial%20velocity">radial velocity</a> is poorly constrained, but it appears to be drifting closer at a rate of around −6 km/s. Pi Piscis Austrini is moving through the <a href="galaxy">galaxy</a> at a velocity of 16.3 km/s relative to the Sun. Its projected galactic orbit carries it between 24,000 and 37,500 light-years from the center of the galaxy.
This is a single-lined <a href="spectroscopic%20binary">spectroscopic binary</a> system with an <a href="orbital%20period">orbital period</a> of 178.3 days and an <a href="orbital%20eccentricity">eccentricity</a> of 0.53. The primary component is an <a href="F-type%20main-sequence%20star">F-type main-sequence star</a> with a <a href="stellar%20classification">stellar classification</a> of . In 1965 it was designated a <a href="classical%20Cepheid%20variable">classical Cepheid variable</a> star with a brightness that ranged from 5.10 to 5.12, but is now considered to be (most likely) constant. It displays an <a href="infrared%20excess">infrared excess</a>, suggesting a <a href="circumstellar%20disk">circumstellar disk</a> is orbiting at a radius of with a mean temperature of 90 K. The cooler secondary companion has a class of F3 V. The system appears to be a source of <a href="X-ray%20astronomy">X-ray emission</a>.
